content.text: Circle the vector quantities in the list.
State the maximum speed of the train.
Describe the motion of the train between station A and station B.
Calculate the distance between station A and station B.
On a different day, the train takes 650 s to travel between station A and station B.
Suggest one change to the motion of the train that leads to this longer journey time.
[Total: 8]
Fig. 1.1 shows the speed-time graph for a train travelling from station A to station B.
State two different changes to the motion that the resultant force may cause.
State one other way that forces may change a stationary object.
A resultant force is applied to an object moving with a velocity \(v\) in a straight line.
Describe how a uniform metre ruler, a pivot and a selection of masses can be used to demonstrate that there is no resultant moment on an object in equilibrium.
You may include a labelled diagram in your answer.
[Total: 7]
A skateboarder is initially at rest at point A. The skateboarder then travels through point B and comes to rest at point C.
Describe the transfer of energy as the skateboarder travels from A to B to C along the concrete track.
B is at ground level and C is at 2.8 m above ground level. The mass of the skateboarder is 65 kg.
Calculate the work done on the skateboarder as she travels from B to C.
The skateboarder falls off the skateboard at B. She hits the track and comes to rest after a few milliseconds.
State the equation that defines the force \(F\) with which the skateboarder hits the track. State the meaning of any symbols you use.
[Total: 6]
Fig. 3.1 shows a side view of part of a concrete track at a skateboard park.
State the main method of thermal energy transfer throughout the air in the room.
Explain how the heater warms all the air in the room.
Show that the current in the heater is approximately 8.7 A.
The plug connecting the heater to the mains supply is fitted with a fuse.
Fuse ratings of 3A, 5A, 10A and 13A are available.
State which fuse is used. Explain your answer.
[Total: 8]
The power of the heater is 2.0kW when it is connected to the mains supply with an e.m.f. of 230 V.
Fig. 4.1 shows a heater used to warm the air in a room.
The refractive index of the soap film is 1.28.
Define refractive index in terms of the speed of light.
Show that the angle of refraction as the light enters the soap film is approximately \(43^{\circ}\).
On Fig. 5.1, carefully draw the refracted light ray in the soap film and label the angle of refraction. [2]
Define monochromatic.
Calculate the frequency of the light.
[Total: 9]
[Turn over]
The ray of light is monochromatic red light with a wavelength of 680 nm in air.
A ray of light is incident on a soap film. Fig. 5.1 shows a magnified image of a small part of the soap film. The ray of light is refracted as it enters the soap film.
soap film
air
Glass is not a magnetic material.
State the difference between magnetic and non-magnetic materials.
Suggest a suitable material for the magnets in the window cleaner. Explain your answer.
Label the poles of the magnets in Fig. 6.2.
State how the field lines in Fig. 6.2 show different strengths of the magnetic field between the magnets.
[Total: 4]
Fig. 6.1 shows a person using a magnetic window cleaner. The part on the outside of the window is attracted to the inside part through the glass window.
Each part of the window cleaner contains two magnets. Fig. 6.2 shows the magnetic field between the parts of the window cleaner.
Name the electrical component.
Explain how you identified the component from the graph in Fig. 7.1.
Draw the circuit symbol for this component.
Fig. 7.1 shows a sketch of the current-voltage graph for an electrical component.
is closed. \(S_{2}\) is open. The reading on the ammeter is 3.9A.
Fig. 7.2 shows an electric circuit for two identical electric heaters, A and B, connected to a mains supply of 230 V.
Identify components A and B in Fig. 8.1.
Component C is made of soft iron.
Describe the effect of this component on the generator.

The coil of the generator rotates at a constant speed of two complete revolutions per second. Sketch a graph of the e.m.f. generated against time on the axes in Fig. 8.2. The coil is in the position shown in Fig. 8.1 at time \(= 0\).
Explain the advantages of transmitting electricity at high voltages.
A power station generates electricity at 25000 V. A transformer steps up the voltage to \(300000V\). The primary coil of the step-up transformer has 450 turns.
Calculate the number of turns \(N_{s}\) on the secondary coil of the transformer.
[Total: 10]
In power stations, transformers are used to step up the voltage of electricity generated before it is transmitted through cables over long distances.
Fig. 8.1 shows a diagram of part of a simple a.c. generator.
Suggest how the nucleus of a stable isotope of strontium differs from a nucleus of strontium-90. Explain your answer.
Complete the nuclide equation for the decay of strontium-90 to yttrium.
Explain why scientists limit the amount of time they are exposed to radioactive strontium.
Use Fig. 9.1 to determine the half-life of yttrium. Show your working.
Explain the difference between the count rate in Table 9.1 and the count rate due to yttrium plotted on the graph in Fig. 9.1.
[Total: 10]
[Turn over
Yttrium is also unstable. A scientist places a sample of yttrium near a radiation detector. Table 9.1 shows the count rate recorded by the detector as the sample decays.
State and explain the difference between the orbital speed of Jupiter and the orbital speed of the Earth.
[Total: 8]

Strontium-90 ( \({ }_{38}^{90} \mathrm{Sr}\) ) is a radioactive isotope that contains 38 protons and 52 neutrons. Strontium-90 decays to form an isotope of yttrium (Y) by emitting beta ( \(\beta\) ) particles.
